turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm thinking about joining my first hackathon. Where do I even start looking for one?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Hello! That's exciting. You can find hackathons listed on platforms like Devpost, Major League Hacking (MLH), or specific tech community websites. Also, check your university's or local tech group's announcements. Do you have any specific interests, like a particular technology or theme?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hmm, not really a specific tech yet. It's more about the theme. I see so many different ones â€“ 'Fintech', 'Healthcare', 'Sustainability'... How do I pick one that I actually have a chance of building something good for? It feels a bit overwhelming.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Picking a theme that interests you is important. Look for themes where you feel you can contribute creative ideas or utilize your existing skills. Sometimes, sponsors provide data or APIs related to the theme, which can guide your project.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Yeah, but that's still pretty vague. What if I don't have specific skills for 'Healthcare'? Do I need to learn a whole new domain in a weekend? What kind of projects actually *win* these things? Is it always the flashiest AI or blockchain projects, or is there room for clever solutions using simpler tech? I really want to build something competitive.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a valid concern. Winning projects often demonstrate innovation, technical execution, relevance to the theme/problem, and a clear presentation. While cutting-edge tech like AI can be impressive, a well-executed, user-friendly application addressing a real problem using simpler technologies can absolutely win. Judges look for novelty, feasibility, impact, and completeness. Focusing on a clear problem and building a functional, polished prototype is often more effective than attempting overly ambitious ideas that don't get finished. Consider projects with strong user interfaces, clear value propositions, or insightful data utilization, regardless of the underlying complexity.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, that makes a lot more sense and makes me feel less stressed about needing to be an AI expert instantly. Thanks for that detailed breakdown! How crucial is having a good team, and any tips on finding teammates?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Having a good team is very crucial. It allows you to distribute tasks, leverage diverse skill sets (design, frontend, backend, pitching), maintain morale, and work more efficiently under pressure. Most hackathons have dedicated channels or events (like team-building mixers) before the coding starts. Look for individuals with complementary skills, enthusiasm for the theme, and a willingness to collaborate. Don't be afraid to talk to people and share your initial ideas to see if there's a good fit.
